If the means of production, as they increase in extent and effective power, become to a less extent means of employment of labourers, this state of things is again modified by the fact that in proportion as the productiveness of labour increases, capital increases its supply of labour more quickly than its demand for labourers. The over-work of the employed part of the working class swells the ranks of the reserve, whilst conversely the greater pressure that the latter by its competition exerts on the former, forces these to submit to over-work and to subjugation under the dictates of capital. The condemnation of one part of the working-class to enforced idleness by the over-work of the other part, and the converse, becomes a means of enriching the individual capitalists,17 and accelerates at the same time the production of the industrial reserve army on a scale corresponding with the advance of social accumulation. How important is this element in the formation of the relative surplus-population, is shown by the example of England. Her technical means for saving labour are colossal. Nevertheless, if to-morrow morning labour generally were reduced to a rational amount, and proportioned to the different sections of the working-class according to age and sex, the working population to hand would be absolutely insufficient for the carrying on of national production on its present scale. The great majority of the labourers now "unproductive" would have to be turned into "productive" ones.
This is the place to return to one of the grand exploits of economic apologetics. It will be remembered that if through the introduction of new, or the extension of old, machinery, a portion of variable capital is transformed into constant, the economic apologist interprets this operation which “fixes” capital and by that very act sets labourers “free,” in exactly the opposite way, pretending that it sets free capital for the labourers. Only now can one fully understand the effrontery of these apologists. What are set free are not only the labourers immediately turned out by the machines, but also their future substitutes in the rising generation, and the additional contingent, that with the usual extension of trade on the old basis would be regularly absorbed. They are now all “set free,” and every new bit of capital looking out for employment can dispose of them. Whether it attracts them or others, the effect on the general labour demand will be nil, if this capital is just sufficient to take out of the market as many labourers as the machines threw upon it. If it employs a smaller number, that of the supernumeraries increases; if it employs a greater, the general demand for labour only increases to the extent of the excess of the employed over those “set free.” The impulse that additional capital, seeking an outlet, would otherwise have given to the general demand for labour, is therefore in every case neutralised to the extent of the labourers thrown out of employment by the machine. That is to say, the mechanism of capitalistic production so manages matters that the absolute increase of capital is accompanied by no corresponding rise in the general demand for labour. And this the apologist calls a compensation for the misery, the sufferings, the possible death of the displaced labourers during the transition period that banishes them into the [[reserve army of labour|industrial reserve army]] out of antagonism of capital accumulation.<ref>"Capital, Volume I", Chapter 25, where he cites his book ''[[The Poverty of Philosophy]]'' (Chapter II, Section 1, 7) to explain this in relation with [[relations of production]]</ref> The demand for labour is not identical with increase of capital, nor supply of labour with increase of the working class. It is not a case of two independent forces working on one another. Les dés sont pipés.
Capital works on both sides at the same time. If its accumulation, on the one hand, increases the demand for labour, it increases on the other the supply of labourers by the “setting free” of them, whilst at the same time the pressure of the unemployed compels those that are employed to furnish more labour, and therefore makes the supply of labour, to a certain extent, independent of the supply of labourers. The action of the law of [[supply and demand]] of labour on this basis completes the [[despotism]] of capital. As soon, therefore, as the labourers learn the secret, how it comes to pass that in the same measure as they work more, as they produce more wealth for others, and as the productive power of their labour increases, so in the same measure even their function as a means of the self-expansion of capital becomes more and more precarious for them; as soon as they discover that the degree of intensity of the competition among themselves depends wholly on the pressure of the relative surplus population; as soon as, by Trades’ Unions, &c., they try to organise a regular co-operation between employed and unemployed in order to destroy or to weaken the ruinous effects of this natural law of capitalistic production on their class, so soon capital and its sycophant, Political Economy, cry out at the infringement of the “eternal” and so to say “sacred” law of supply and demand. Every combination of employed and unemployed disturbs the “harmonious” action of this law. But, on the other hand, as soon as (in the colonies, e.g.) adverse circumstances prevent the creation of an [[reserve army of labour|industrial reserve army]] and, with it, the absolute dependence of the working class upon the capitalist class, capital, along with its commonplace Sancho Panza, rebels against the “sacred” law of supply and demand, and tries to check its inconvenient action by forcible means and State interference.
==Part Eight: Primitive Accumulation==
===Chapter 26: The Secret of Primitive Accumulation=== In order to understand the desire for and techniques utilized by the [[bourgeoisie]] to accumulate capital before the rise of capitalism itself, one must look to the notion of [[Primitive accumulation of capital|primitive accumulation]] as the main impetus for this drastic change in [[Human history|history]]. Primitive accumulation refers to the essential lucrative method employed by the capitalist class that brought about the transition in to the capitalist mode of production following the end of the [[Feudalism|feudal system]].{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=874}} Karl Marx states that the means of production and a bare level of subsistence must be stripped from the common producer to allow for this to take place.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=875}} The means of production refers to the tools or processes used to create a [[product (business)|product]] or provide a [[service (economics)|service]].
===Chapter 27: Expropriation of the Agricultural Population From the Land=== The central process for and secret behind primitive accumulation involved the [[Enclosure|expropriation of agricultural lands]] and any form of wealth from the population of commoners by the capitalists, which typically was characterized by brutal and violent struggles between the two opposing classes.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=885}} Since the peasantry was not subjected to the laws of feudalism any longer, they were ultimately freed from their [[Landlord|lords]] and the land to assimilate into this new mode of production as a wage laborer.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=874}} Every freed [[proletariat]] as a result had only their labor power to sell to the bourgeoisie to meet their needs to simply survive.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=874}}
Marx refers to the [[Inclosure Act 1489]],<ref>Act of Henry VII., 1489, cap. 19</ref> the [[Inclosure Act 1533]],<ref>Act, 25 Henry VIII.</ref> and the [[Poor Relief Act 1601]].<ref>43 Eliz. 1 c. 2, introducing the poor rate, declared perpetual by the statute of the 16th year of Charles I., ch. 4</ref>
===Chapter 28: Bloody Legislation Against the Expropriated, from the End of the 15th Century. Forcing Down of Wages by Acts of Parliament=== Unfortunately, the integration process into this new mode of production came at a cost to the proletariat since the strenuous demands of finding alternative work proved to be too much of a burden for most. As a result, the working class often initially resorted to [[Theft|thievery]] and [[begging]] to meet their needs under this new form of human existence.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=888}} To make matters worse, harsh legislation seen in England and France as Marx points out declared these individuals to be [[vagabond (person)|vagabond]]s and [[Rogue (vagrant)|rogues]] subject to the laws of the state.{{sfn|Marx|1990|pp=887–889}} Furthermore, the working class also suffered due to legislative measures taken in England to keep working wages astonishingly low while the [[cost of living]] rose.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=901}}
Marx refers, in particular, to the [[Vagabonds Act of 1530]],<ref>22 Henry VIII c.12, beggars had to be licensed, but if somebody begged and they were well, they would be whipped.</ref> the [[Act for Punishment of Sturdy Vagabonds and Beggars 1536]],<ref>27 Hen VIII c. 25</ref> the [[Vagabonds Act 1547]],<ref>1 Edw. VI c. 3, allowing someone to take as a slave the person they accurately denounce as an idler if they refused to work</ref> the [[Vagabonds Act 1572]],<ref>14 Eliz. I c. 5, providing unlicensed beggars above 14 years of age are to be severely flogged</ref> the [[Poor Act 1575]],<ref>Marx cites 18 Elizabeth, c. 13, although it appears to be c. 3</ref> the [[Vagabonds Act 1597]],<ref>9 Eliz. c. 4, introducing [[penal transportation]]</ref> and the [[Vagabonds Act 1603]].<ref>1 Jas. I c. 7</ref> which was only repealed by the [[Vagrants Act 1713]].<ref>Marx cites this as 12 Anne, c. 23. although it appears to be c. 26 in other sources.</ref>
Marx also recounts wage fixing legislation, including the [[Statute of Labourers 1351]], the [[Statute of Apprentices]] (which was extended to weavers by James I), the [[Journeymen Tailors, London Act 1720]],<ref>Marx appears to refer to this (forbidding "a higher day’s wage than 2s. 71⁄2d. for journeymen tailors in and around London"), but cites "8 George II." where there does not appear to be such a law. The 1720 Act was 7 Geo. 1 St. 1 c. 13</ref> the [[Silk Manufacturers Act 1772]],<ref>13 George III., c. 68, leaving silk weaver wages to be regulated by justices of the peace.</ref> and the [[Colliers (Scotland) Act 1799]].<ref>39 Geo. 3 c. 56, stating "wages of the Scotch miners should continue to be regulated by a statute of Elizabeth and two Scotch acts of 1661 and 1671."</ref>
===Chapter 29: Genesis of the Capitalist Farmer=== The origin of the capitalists in England spawned out of the "[[Landed property|great landed proprietors]]" who reaped the benefits of the surplus value made from the expropriated land they had acquired at practically no cost. The progressive fall of the value of [[precious metals]] and money brought more profit to the capitalist farmers as the wage laborers beneath them were forced to accept lower wages.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=906}} It comes as no surprise that the class of capitalist farmers in England became enormously wealthy given the circumstances of the time.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=907}}
===Chapter 30: Reaction of the Agricultural Revolution on Industry. Creation of the Home-Market for Industrial Capital=== The [[British Agricultural Revolution]] (17th–19th centuries) not only caused many changes in the way people worked but in social structure as well. When industrialization provided the cheapest and most efficient tools for agricultural production, it caused a reduced need for the peasant [[Farmworker|farm workers]], which displaced most of the working class from the countryside. Faced with the choice of selling their labor for a wage or becoming a capitalist, there emerged a class of [[entrepreneur]]s who through the exploitation of wage laborers became the capitalist class. As the system grew, there became a need for cheaper and more readily available materials. Thus [[Colonialism|colonization]] was born. By expanding into new territories and enslaving indigenous cultures, primitive accumulation became a source of quick and easy capital. [[Famine]] even became a tool for capitalists in 1769–1770 when England raised the price of rice in India so that only the rich could afford it.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=917}} [[Government debt|National debt]] soon became a tool of control for capitalists who turned unproductive money into capital through lending and exchange. Encouraged to participate in the creation of debt, each worker participates in the creation of "[[Joint-stock company|joint-stock companies]], the [[Stock exchange|stock-exchange]], and modern [[bankocracy]]."{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=919}} The international credit system conceals the source of its generation; the exploitation of slave and wage laborers.
===Chapter 31: The Genesis of the Industrial Capitalist=== The shift in the ownership of the means of production from the proletariat to the bourgeoisie left the common producer with only his labor power to sell. This means they are free proprietors of the conditions of their labor.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=927}} During this process of transference, [[private property]] was replaced by capitalist private property through the highest form of exploitation, and the shift from the days of free labor to wage labor had taken place. Capitalist private property was formed from the capital mode of appropriation, which dwindled away the once existent private property founded on the personal labor of workers.
===Chapter 32: Historical Tendency of Capitalist Accumulation=== Marx states that as capitalism grows the number of wage laborers grows exponentially. Therefore, ultimately there will be a revolution in which the capitalists are expropriated from their means of wealth by the majority. In other words, the seeds of destruction are already implanted within capitalism. Marx stresses that the demise of capitalism does not necessarily mean the return of feudalism and private property, but rather "it does indeed establish individual property on the basis of the achievements of the capitalist era: namely [[Cooperation|co-operation]] and the [[Cooperative|possession in common]] of the land and the means of production produced by labor itself".{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=929}} That is to say that the transformation will revert to the time where private property is seen as social property.
===Chapter 33: The Modern Theory of Colonisation=== Marx claims that two types of private property exist in a [[political economy]]. The first form is the labor of the producer himself and the other form rests in a capitalist's exploitation of others. In the industrialized capitalist world of [[Western Europe]], this is easily attained through the usage of laws and private property. However, capitalists constantly find obstacles in the colonies where workers work for their own enrichment rather than that of the capitalist. Capitalists overcome this obstacle by the use of force and by the political backing of the "mother land". If domination over the workers free will cannot be achieved, Marx then asks, "how did capital and wage-labour come into existence?"{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=933}} This comes about through the division of workers into owners of capital and owners of labor. This system causes workers to essentially expropriate themselves in order to accumulate capital.{{sfn|Marx|1990|p=934}} This self-expropriation served as primitive accumulation for the capitalists, and therefore, was the catalyst for capitalism in the [[colony|colonies]].

revision.comment: +[[Category:Female legendary creatures]]; ±[[Category:Indian folklore]]→[[Category:Indian legendary creatures]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Chedipe''' (literally "prostitute"<ref name="melton">{{Cite book | last = Melton| first = J. Gordon| title = The Vampire Book: The Encyclopedia of the Undead | publisher = Visible Ink Press | year = 1999| location = | page = 372| isbn=978-1-57859-281-4}}</ref>) is a witch-vampire in the [[Indian folklore|folklore]] of the region around the [[Godavari River]] in India.<ref name="melton"/> They are associated with the ''[[devadasi]]s'', girls who were dedicated to a Hindu temple god and were often treated as temple prostitutes.<ref name="Bane">{{cite book|author=Bane, Theresa|title=Encyclopedia of Vampire Mythology|date=2010|publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0786444526|page=44|chapter = Chedipe}}</ref> Women who die an unnatural death, such as in childbirth or by suicide, and prostitutes may become chedipes.<ref name="Bane"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Enright|first=Laura L.|title=Vampires' Most Wanted: The Top 10 Book of Bloodthirsty Biters, Stake-wielding Slayers, and Other Undead Oddities|year=2011|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=1-597-97678-4}}</ref> Chedipes are sometimes characterized as being undead.
The chedipe is described as a vulgar woman riding on a tiger in the moonlit night.<ref name="melton"/><ref name="MaberryKramer2009"/> The typical chedipe story carries out with them choosing a house and magically forcing the closed doors of the house open, to which she enters naked.<ref name="melton"/><ref name = "thurston">{{cite book|author=[[Edgar Thurston]]|title=Omens and Superstitions of Southern India|year=1912|publisher=|url=https://archive.org/stream/omenssuperstitio00thur#page/260/mode/2up|pages=261–2}}</ref> She casts a spell on the residents of the home, putting them in a deep sleep. She then sucks the blood of all of the men in the house through their toes.<ref name="Bane"/> Some traditions say that she feasts only on the strongest man of the house.<ref name="MaberryKramer2009">{{cite book|author1=[[Jonathan Maberry]]|author2=Da Kramer|title=THEY BITE!: Endless Cravings of Supernatural Predators|date=2008|publisher=Citadel Press|isbn=978-0-8065-2820-5|page=63|chapter = They Thirst: Vampres}}</ref> Others suggest that the chedipe targets only the man whom she dislikes.<ref name = "thurston"/> In the morning, the victim of the chedipe will awaken from their sleep with no memory of the chedipe's visit. He will be sapped of his virility and will feel uneasy and slightly intoxicated for the entirety of the following day. If he does not receive medical treatment, the chedipe will return.<ref name="melton"/><ref name = "thurston"/> In another narrative, she is described as returning repeatedly before the victim can recover from the blood and energy loss, thus weakening him further. If he is not treated, the man withers away and dies.<ref name="MaberryKramer2009"/>
The chedipe also has sexual intercourse with the sleeping victim in many cases, resulting in suspicions of infidelity in the mind of the victim's wife. This shatters the marital concord of the household, ending love and trust in the family. The chedipe feasts on the resulting sadness and pain.<ref name="MaberryKramer2009"/> She may also pluck out the tongue of her victim, instantaneously killing him. The chedipe may also inflict wounds on the skin and insert sticks in the body of the man, which will burn like fire.<ref name = "thurston"/>
Sometimes, the chedipe undresses and turns into a tiger with one human leg and attacks men in the forest.<ref name="melton"/> This form is known as ''Murulupuli'' ("enchanting tiger"). If the man retaliates with a weapon, she flees. If someone recognizes her in the tiger form, she assumes her real form and pretends to be digging for roots in the jungle.<ref name = "thurston"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Vampires]] [[Category:Indian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Demons in Hinduism]] [[Category:Witchcraft in folklore and mythology]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]]

'''Colorsport Images Ltd''' is a sports photographic archive and agency, containing around 10 million images covering almost 150 years of sport, serving all forms of media outlets. The Colorsport partnership was set up in the late 1960s by [[photographers]] [[Colin Elsey]] and Stewart Fraser, and they were soon joined by Andrew Cowie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digbee.com/photoarchivenews/december03issue/|title=In Memory|publisher= Photo Archive News|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref>
The agency – as its name suggests - was among the earliest to cover sport in colour as well as black and white, especially [[association football|football]], [[rugby union]] and the [[Olympics]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Taylor |first= John |author2=Colin Elsey |title= [[Rugby In Focus]] |publisher= [[David & Charles]] |date=November 1986 |isbn= 0-7153-8882-7}}</ref>
==History== The business was established in the late 1960s when two sports photographers, Colin Elsey and Stewart Fraser, started to work together. They were initially based in Kings Cross before the business became established at St Peter’s Street in [[Islington]] for many years as it continued to expand. During that time Colorsport was the official photographer for the [[Rugby Football Union]] and [[Arsenal Football Club]], as well as many sporting publications.
In 2003 the business, which had moved to Crouch End, lost [[Colin Elsey]] who died suddenly.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/2420875/Obituary-Elsey-leaves-a-lasting-image.html|title=Obituary - Elsey leaves a lasting image|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=24 January 2012|location=London|first=Brendan|last=Gallagher|date=10 September 2003}}</ref> At around the same time Stewart Fraser retired.
Colorsport gained new owners in late 2005, notably Nigel Wray, the owner of Saracens rugby club, and David Norrie, a former editor of [[Rugby World]] magazine and cricket and rugby correspondent of the [[News of the World]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsjournalists.co.uk/members-news/norrie-the-latest-to-join-wapping-exodus/|title=Norrie the latest to join Wapping exodus|publisher=Sports Journalists' Association|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> who became chairman. The business was moved to extensive new head offices in Surrey.
Andrew Cowie, who joined the business in 1972, is still active as a sports photographer and also now heads up Colorsport's library operations.
James Pinniger joined as Chief Executive at the start of 2009 from [[Reuters]]. Since that time Colorsport has revamped their online presence<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastwebmedia.com/news/fwm-in-the-frame-for-colorsport/2011-04-01/|title=FWM in the Frame for Colorsport|publisher=[[Fast Web Media]]|accessdate=24 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://inbedwithmaradona.com/journal/2011/6/16/ibwm-and-colorsport.html|title=IBWM and Colorsport|publisher=In Bed With Maradona|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sis.tv/news/sis-picture|title=SIS in the picture|publisher=[[Satellite Information Services]]|accessdate=27 January 2012}}</ref> and developed a network of international partners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://a24media.com/index.php/news/random/2740-partnership|title=Colorsport Partnership|publisher=A24 Media|accessdate=21 February 2012}}</ref> Colorsport photographers were nominated in two categories at the 2012 SJA British Sport Photography Awards,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsjournalists.co.uk/photography/british-sports-photography-awards-the-shortlists//|title=British Sports Photography Awards: shortlists|publisher=Sports Journalists' Association|accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> while Cowie's shot of [[Tony Woodcock (rugby player)|Tony Woodcock]]'s try for the [[All Blacks]] in the [[2011 Rugby World Cup Final]] was voted the Sports Picture of the Year at the 2012 NAPA Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.napa.org.uk/users/awards.php|title=NAPA Awards 2012|publisher=National Association of Press Agencies|accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref>
==The Archive== Colorsport Images has acquired a number of older photo archives, principally the Albert Wilkes Collection, The Provincial Press Archive, and the Barrett Collection.
Colorsport has [[digitizing|digitised]] these collections, enabling online distribution. They now operate a large [[Electronic commerce|commercial website]] which allows clients to search and browse for images, purchase usage rights and download images,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.colorsport.co.uk|title=Colorsport International Sports Archive|publisher=Colorsport|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> in addition to a separate website that enables selected images from the archive to be ordered as consumer prints.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prints.colorsport.co.uk/|title=Colorsport Prints|publisher=Colorsport & Media Storehouse|accessdate=25 January 2013}}</ref>
The Wilkes Collection, which contains many thousands of glass plates (mainly football and cricket), had been set up in the 1890s by [[Albert Wilkes]], who played football for Aston Villa and England. Wilkes, and later his son, ran the business from West Bromwich for over sixty years.
Provincial Press had been based in Southport from the 1940s through to the 1970s, covering many FA Cup Finals, including the 1953 [[Matthews Final]], as well as having contracts with Manchester United, Liverpool, Chelsea, Newcastle United and Arsenal football clubs among others.
==Photographers== Colin Elsey’s reputation as one of rugby union's leading photographer was established with his work on the all-conquering [[1974 British Lions tour to South Africa]] and confirmed on the [[1977 British Lions tour to New Zealand|next Lions tour to New Zealand]] three years later when he took the iconic “Mudman” image of Fran Cotton peering out of the Wellington mud, considered by many to be among the greatest rugby photos ever taken.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-1220638/THE-LIST-50-great-sporting-photographs-Nos-10-1.html|title=50 Great Sporting Photographs Number 5 - The Mudman|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=24 January 2012|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/international/britishandirishlionsrugby/5252914/The-Lions-Dream-Team.html|title=The Lions Dream Team|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=24 January 2012|location=London|first=Brendan|last=Gallagher|date=30 April 2009}}</ref>
Stewart Fraser, a winner of the 1967 World Press Photo sports award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archive.worldpressphoto.org/search/layout/result/indeling/detailwpp/form/wpp/start/3/q/ishoofdafbeelding/true/trefwoord/year/1967/trefwoord/nationality/United%20Kingdom|title=World Press Photo 1967, Stewart Fraser, 1st prize, Sports |publisher=World Press Photo|accessdate=24 January 2012}}</ref> became a specialist in covering winter and summer [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] sports.
Andrew Cowie took up the mantle as Colorsport's soccer specialist - in 2010 in South Africa he covered his eighth World Cup for the company.
Several other distinguished photographers learnt their trade and came through the Colorsport ranks, such as Stuart McFarlane<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/meet-the-club-photographer-stuart-macfarlane|title=Stuart Macfarlane - Arsenal Club Photographer|publisher=Arsenal Football Club|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> and Matthew Impey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiredphotos.co.uk/about|title=Matthew Impey - Wired Photos|publisher=wiredphotos.co.uk|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref>
Current Colorsport photographers include Dan Rowley,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danrowley.co.uk/dr/|title=Dan Rowley |publisher=www.danrowley.co.uk|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> Ian MacNicol,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmediascotland.com/press_news/31282/strong-scots-presence-on-picture-editors--shortlist|title=Strong Scots Presence on Picture Editors' Shortlist |publisher=AllmediaScotland|accessdate=24 January 2012}}</ref> and Shaun Boggust.
==External links== * [http://business.colorsport.co.uk/ Colorsport Images] * [http://prints.colorsport.co.uk/ Colorsport Print Sales] * [https://twitter.com/colorsport/ Colorsport on Twitter] * [http://www.photoarchivenews.com/important-sports-photo-agency-reaches-300k-images-online/ Colorsport Archive Reaches 300k]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Photo archives]] [[Category:Companies based in Surrey]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category OS X-only software to [[:Category:MacOS-only software]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 October 8]].
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox Software | name = DVDpedia | logo = <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:DVDpediaLogo.png|48px|CDpedia]] --> | screenshot = <!-- [[Image:DVDpediaScreenshot.png--> | caption = Screenshot of DVDpedia | developer = [[Bruji]] | latest_release_version = 5.1.1 | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2012|06|16}} | latest_preview_version = | latest_preview_date = | operating_system = [[Mac OS X]] | genre = [[Cataloging]] | license = [[Shareware]] | website = {{URL|http://www.bruji.com/dvdpedia}} }} '''DVDpedia''' is a [[DVD]] cataloging application for [[Mac OS X]] developed by [[Bruji]]. DVDpedia is [[shareware]] and is limited to 25 entries until purchased.
The program searches the [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] sites (US, UK, Canada, France, Germany and Japan) plus [[IMDb]] and several other international sites for information about DVDs, either by entering a keyword or using a [[Image scanner|scanner]] or [[iSight]]. Users can create smart collections and start a wish list and a borrowed list Entries can be viewed as a standard list, browsed by cover or in the full screen view. The [[HTML]] export templates are customizable. DVDpedia comes with [[Spotlight (software)|Spotlight]] integration.
==Features== * Export options, including [[HTML]], [[PHP]], [[SQL]], text, iPod, and direct to [[.Mac]] * Smart collections * Support for barcode scanner including the [[CueCat|:CueCat]] * [[Address Book (Mac OS X)|Address Book]] integration. * [[Dashboard (Mac OS)|Dashboard]] [[Widget (computing)|widget]] for internal search and Amazon web search. * Localized in French, German, Spanish, Italian and Dutch. * Plug-in architecture for extensibility * 100% [[Cocoa (API)|Cocoa]] * [[QuickTime]] movie view for linking trailers
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.bruji.com/dvdpedia}} *[http://download.cnet.com/DVDpedia/3000-2130_4-10403970.html Version tracker] *[http://www.macupdate.com/info.php/id/14070 MacUpdate] *[http://www.osnews.com/story.php?news_id=7554 OSNews review 8.5/10]
[[Category:MacOS-only software]] [[Category:Personal information managers]] [[Category:Shareware]]

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=February 2013}} '''''Hassam v Jacobs NO and Others''''',<ref>2009 (5) SA 572 (CC).</ref> an important case in South African law, was heard in the Constitutional Court<ref>Langa CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Cameron J, Mokgoro J, Ngcobo J, Nkabinde J, O'Regan J, Sachs J, Skweyiya J, Van Der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J.</ref> on 19 February 2009, with judgment handed down on 15 July. The applicant was a party to a polygamous Muslim marriage, whose husband had died intestate. The Constitutional Court held that precluding the applicant from inheriting unfairly discriminated on the grounds of religion, marital status and gender, and was therefore inconsistent with section 9 of the Constitution. Accordingly, it was held that the applicant could inherit. The ambit of this judgment extended the ruling in ''[[Daniels v Campbell]]'' to polygamous Muslim marriages.
== Facts == The question was whether or not the benefits provided by the [[Intestate Succession Act]]<ref>Act 81 of 1987.</ref>) and the [[Maintenance Act]]<ref>Act 27 of 1990.</ref> accrue to surviving spouses of polygynous Muslim marriages. The objective of the legislation is to ensure that widows receive at least a child's share of their spouse's estates instead of being left precariously dependant on family benevolence.
The Cape High Court found the Intestate Succession Act,<ref>s 1(4)(f).</ref> in discriminating on grounds of gender and religion and marital status, to be inconsistent with the Constitution. The word "spouse" in the Act should be interpreted henceforth to include partners in polygynous Muslim marriages, while "survivor" in the Maintenance Act should be read to include surviving partners of polygynous Muslim marriages.
== Judgment == In the Constitutional Court, however, "spouse" was found not to be reasonably capable of being understood to include more than one partner in the context of a polygynous Muslim marriage. The words "or spouses," therefore, are henceforth to be read in after each use of the word "spouse" in the Act.
== See also == * [[South African family law]]
== References == === Cases === * ''Hassam v Jacobs NO and Others'' 2009 (5) SA 572 (CC).
== Statutes == * [[Intestate Succession Act]] 81 of 1987. * [[Maintenance Act|Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act]] 27 of 1990.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Constitutional Court of South Africa cases]] [[Category:2009 in South African law]] [[Category:2009 in case law]] [[Category:South African family case law]]

A policy based consensus has been reached to remove this section from professional wrestling articles [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#Should the "In wrestling" section be removed from professional wrestling articles|Here]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name=Ilio DiPaolo |names=Ilio DiPaolo |image=Ilio DiPaolo.jpg |image_size=200px |caption= |height= |weight= |real_height= |real_weight= |birth_date=November 7, 1926 |birth_place=[[Introdacqua|Introdacqua (AQ)]], [[Abruzzo]], [[Italy]]<ref name=slam>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBios/dipaulo.html|title=Canadian Hall of Fame: Ilio DiPaolo|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=2009-12-28|author=Key, George}}</ref> |death_date=May 10, 1995, aged 68 |death_place=[[Hamburg, New York]] |resides= |billed= |trainer=[[Toots Mondt]] |debut=1949<ref name=slam/> |retired=1965<ref name=slam/> |website= }} '''Ilio DiPaolo''' (November 7, 1926 – May 10, 1995), was an [[Italians|Italian]] [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] and restaurateur who lived in the [[Buffalo, New York]] area.
==Professional wrestling career== DiPaolo was born in Italy and lived there until he moved to Venezuela in 1949.<ref name=slam/> There, he met [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Promoter|promoter]] [[Toots Mondt]], who taught him to wrestle.<ref name=slam/> While waiting to get the proper paperwork to move to the United States, he relocated to the Dominican Republic to wrestle in the meantime.<ref name=slam/> After the paperwork was completed, he moved to [[Buffalo, New York]] in 1951.<ref name=rest/> He then began to work for [[Frank Tunney]] out of the Toronto area.<ref name=slam/> Around this time he teamed with [[Whipper Billy Watson]] to win the [[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship]].<ref name=slam/>
After wrestling around the world, he returned to Toronto in 1968 to wrestle [[Pat O'Connor (wrestler)|Pat O'Connor]] for the World Championship, but the match went to a one-hour time limit draw.<ref name=slam/> His last match was against [[Lou Thesz]] for the same title; a match that also went to a one-hour time limit draw.<ref name=slam/>
==Personal life== DiPaolo met his wife Ethel, stepdaughter of promoter Pedro Martinez, in 1952.<ref name=rest/> The couple had four children.<ref name=rest/>
He opened his first restaurant, a pizzeria, when he was in his 40s, but it was destroyed by a fire.<ref name=rest/> DiPaolo retired from wrestling full-time in 1965 and opened his second restaurant, an eponymous Italian restaurant now known as "[[Ilio DiPaolo's]]" in [[Blasdell, New York]].<ref name=slam/><ref name=rest/> He died in 1995 after being struck by a car during a torrential downpour while trying to enter a restaurant with his wife.<ref name=slam/> After his death, DiPaolo's oldest son Dennis began to run the restaurant.<ref name=rest>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2005/05/04/1025561.html|title=DiPaolo's Restaurant celebrates 40 years|author=Oliver, Greg|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=2009-12-28|date=May 12, 2005}}</ref> His other children also worked in the restaurant.<ref name=rest/>
[[World Championship Wrestling]] held the [[Ilio DiPaolo Memorial Show]] for DiPaolo from 1996 through 1999. To this point over $750,000 has been raised for the Ilio DiPaolo Scholarship Fund and for other Buffalo charities like Children's Hospital and People Inc.
DiPaolo was selected as a New York State Award recipient by the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2003.<ref name="pwhf">{{cite web|url=http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/bios/dipaolo.asp|title=Ilio Dipaolo|author=Beyer, Dick|publisher=[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]|accessdate=2009-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330194957/http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/bios/dipaolo.asp|archivedate=2010-03-30|df=}}</ref> The DiPaolo family has also been inducted into the New York Chapter of the National Wrestling Hall of Fame for the creation of the Ilio DiPaolo Scholarship fund and continual contribution to high school wrestling.
==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Cauliflower Alley Club]]''' :*Other honoree ([[Cauliflower Alley Club#1994|1994]])
*'''Greater Buffalo Sports Hall of Fame''' :*1996 inductee
*'''[[Maple Leaf Wrestling]]''' :*[[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Canadian Open Tag Team Championship#Title history|5 times]]) - with [[Whipper Billy Watson]] (4) and [[Billy Red Lyons]] (1)
*'''Midwest Wrestling Association''' :*MWA Ohio Heavyweight Championship (3 times) :*MWA Ohio Tag Team Championship (1 time) - with Athol Layton
*'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]''' :*New York State Award (2003)<ref name=pwhf/>
*'''[[Worldwide Wrestling Associates]]''' :*[[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship]] ([[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship#title history|1 time]]) - with Tex Mckenzie
*'''[[Stampede Wrestling]]''' :*[[NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship (Calgary version)|NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship ''(Calgary version)'']] ([[NWA Canadian Tag Team Championship (Calgary version)#Title history|1 time]]) - with Tex McKenzie
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} *[http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBios/dipaulo.html Canadian Wrestling Hall of Fame - Profile] *[http://www.iliodipaolos.com/ Ilio DiPaolo's Restaurant and Ringside Lounge]
{{NWA World Tag Team Champions (Buffalo Athletic Club version)}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dipaolo, Ilio}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:Italian male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]

page.title: International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres

revision.comment: added [[Category:Music organizations based in France]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres''' (IAML), also known as ''Association Internationale des Bibliothèques, Archives et Centres de Documentation Musicaux'' (AIBM) and ''Internationale Vereinigung der Musikbibliotheken, Musikarchive und Musikdokumentationszentren'' (IVMB), is an organisation of [[library|libraries]] with music departments, [[music conservatory]] libraries, radio and orchestra archives, university institutes, music documentation centers, music publishers, and music dealers that fosters international cooperation and promotes music [[bibliography]] and music [[library science]].<ref name=ALA>{{cite book|editor-first=Robert |editor-last=Wedgeworth |title=World Encyclopedia of Library and Information Services |date=1993 |publisher=[[American Library Association]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HSFu99FCJwQC&pg=PA371&dq=International+Association+of+Music+Libraries,+Archives+and+Documentation+Centres&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OCdRUtG6EYjNswa384GYBw&ved=0CGgQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=International%20Association%20of%20Music%20Libraries%2C%20Archives%20and%20Documentation%20Centres&f=false |isbn=9780838906095}}</ref> It was founded in Paris in 1951<ref>{{cite book|title=Harrod's Librarians' Glossary and Reference Book |editor-first=Raymond John |editor-last=Prytherch|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zoCfMEscyzwC&pg=PA364&dq=International+Association+of+Music+Libraries,+Archives+and+Documentation+Centres&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OCdRUtG6EYjNswa384GYBw&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=International%20Association%20of%20Music%20Libraries%2C%20Archives%20and%20Documentation%20Centres&f=false |publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]] |date=2005 |isbn=9781409486152}}</ref> and its three official languages are English, German, and French.
==History== IAML was founded after [[World War II]] to "promote international cooperation and standardization in such matters as [[cataloging]], standards of service, personnel training and the exchange of materials between [[libraries]]."<ref name=Lonn>Anders Lönn, "International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres," The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 2nd edition, 2002, vol. 12, p. 491. {{ISBN|0-333-60800-3}}</ref> The founding of IAML was a three-year process from 1949 to 1951. It was part of the [[United Nations]]' mission to promote world peace. The founding conferences were held in [[Basel]] and [[Florence]] in 1949, in [[Lüneburg]] in 1950, and in [[Paris]] in 1951, the last one conducted by [[UNESCO]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Music Librarianship in the United Kingdom |editor-first=Richard |editor-last=Turbet |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zoCfMEscyzwC&pg=PA364&dq=International+Association+of+Music+Libraries,+Archives+and+Documentation+Centres&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OCdRUtG6EYjNswa384GYBw&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=International%20Association%20of%20Music%20Libraries%2C%20Archives%20and%20Documentation%20Centres&f=false |date=2003 |publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]] |isbn=9780754605720}}</ref>
The Accademia Nazionale [[Luigi Cherubini]] celebrated its 100th anniversary in 1949, an event that brought around 60 music librarians, musicologists, and museum professionals from twelve countries to [[Florence]].<ref name=Geering /> This was the first meeting of music librarians from around the world; plans for a separate organization had been discussed since the founding of the [[International Musicological Society]] in 1927, but the [[Second World War]] prevented anything from taking shape.<ref name="Pleßke">{{cite journal|last=Pleßke|first=Hans-Martin|title=Geschichte und Funktion der Internationalen Vereinigung der Musikbibliotheken (IVMB)|journal=Zentralblatt für Bibliothekswesen|date=1972|volume=86|issue=6|pages=352–359}}</ref> The war had caused heavy losses at many [[libraries]], and international cooperation was of utmost importance.
The goals of the Florence conference included updating the status and locations of the musical sources described in {{Interlanguage link multi|Robert Eitner's|de}} ''Biographisch-Bibliographisches Quellen-Lexikon der Musiker und Musikgelehrten der christlichen Zeitrechnung bis zur Mitte des neunzehnten Jahrhunderts'' ([[Leipzig]], 1900–1904), establishing a central office in each country responsible for [[Microform|microfilming]] musical sources from before 1800, and addressing issues related to [[Music librarianship#Cataloging and Classification|music cataloging]].<ref name=Geering /> The first goal was realized in 1952 with the founding of the [[Répertoire International des Sources Musicales]].
In 1952, IAML had 224 members in 20 countries.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Membership grew to about 1,100 members in 39 countries in 1969<ref>{{cite journal|title=The International Association of Music Libraries |journal=[[Notes (journal)|Notes]] |first=Thor E. |last=Wood |pages=697–699 |volume=25 |issue=4 |date= June 1959 |jstor=896620}}</ref> and 1,850 members in 40 countries in 1991,<ref name=ALA /> with national branches in 26 countries as of 2017.
IAML has professional sections, subject sections, study group, and project groups that focus on particular aspects of music librarianship and documentation. Two professional organizations, [[the International Association of Music Information Centres]] and the [[International Association of Sound and Audiovisual Archives]] began as IAML groups but later formed their own organizations.<ref name=Lonn />
==Structure== The IAML board of directors is made up of the [[president]], past president, [[Secretary (club)|secretary general]], [[treasurer]], and [[vice presidents]].<ref name=Meinhold>{{cite book|last=Meinhold|first=Alexandra|title=World Guide to Library, Archive, and Information Science Associations|date=2010|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|location=Berlin|isbn=9783110226379|pages=28–30}}</ref> The board governs IAML together with a Council (which includes representatives from national branches and professional sections) and the General Assembly.
IAML is affiliated with the [[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]] (IFLA), the [[International Music Council]], and the IMS.<ref name=Meinhold />
==Activities== IAML holds annual conferences and has implemented four main programmes, together known as the "R projects" of [[musicology]]: ''Répertoire international des sources musicales'' (RISM), ''[[Répertoire International de Littérature Musicale|Répertoire international de littérature musicale]]'' (RILM), ''Répertoire international d'iconographie musicale'' (RIdIM) and ''[[Répertoire international de la presse musicale]]'' (RIPM). IAML publishes a journal, ''Fontes Artis Musicae'', with articles on music librarianship and bibliography as well as reports on IAML conferences and on the progress of the "R projects".<ref name=ALA />
===Annual Conferences=== IAML holds annual meetings in different locations around the world. Occasionally, meetings are held jointly with other professional organizations. After the founding meetings held from 1949-1951, annual meetings commenced in 1954.<ref name=Geering>{{cite journal|last=Geering|first=Mireille|title=Geschichte und Gegenwart der AIBM|journal=Forum Musikbibliothek|date=1991|volume=3|pages=197–212. The locations of conferences from 1954–1996 are taken from this source.}}</ref>
* 1954: [[Paris]] * 1955: [[Brussels]] * 1956: [[London]] * 1957: [[Kassel]] * 1958: [[Salzburg]] * 1959: [[Cambridge]], [[UK]] * 1960: [[Amsterdam]] * 1961: [[Lausanne]] * 1962: [[Stockholm]] * 1963: [[Milan]] * 1964: [[Aarhus]] * 1965: [[Dijon]] * 1966: [[Warsaw]] * 1967: [[Salzburg]] * 1968: [[Washington, DC]] * 1969: [[Amsterdam]] * 1970: [[Leipzig]] * 1971: [[St. Gallen]] * 1972: [[Bologna]] * 1973: [[London]] * 1974: [[Jerusalem]] * 1975: [[Montréal]] * 1976: [[Bergen]] * 1977: [[Mainz]] (together with the {{Interlanguage link multi|national German branch|de|3=Internationale_Vereinigung_der_Musikbibliotheken,_Musikarchive_und_Musikdokumentationszentren#L.C3.A4ndergruppe_Deutschland}})<ref name=Geering /> * 1978: [[Lisbon]] * 1979: [[Salzburg]] * 1980: [[Cambridge]], [[UK]] * 1981: [[Budapest]] * 1982: [[Brussels]] * 1983: [[Washington, DC]] * 1984: [[Como]] * 1985: [[East Berlin]] * 1986: [[Stockholm]] * 1987: [[Amsterdam]] * 1988: [[Tokyo]] * 1989: [[Oxford]] * 1990: [[Boulogne-Billancourt]] * 1991: [[Prague]] * 1992: [[Frankfurt am Main]] (together with the {{Interlanguage link multi|national German branch|de|3=Internationale_Vereinigung_der_Musikbibliotheken,_Musikarchive_und_Musikdokumentationszentren#L.C3.A4ndergruppe_Deutschland}})<ref name=Geering /> * 1993: [[Helsinki]] * 1994: [[Ottawa]] * 1995: [[Helsingør]] * 1996: [[Perugia]] * 1997: [[Geneva]] * 1998: [[San Sebastián]] * 1999: [[Wellington]] * 2000: [[Edinburgh]] * 2001: [[Périgueux]] * 2002: [[Berkeley, California]] * 2003: [[Tallinn]] * 2004: [[Oslo]] * 2005: [[Warsaw]] * 2006: [[Gothenburg]] * 2007: [[Sydney]] * 2008: [[Naples]] * 2009: [[Amsterdam]] * 2010: [[Moscow]] * 2011: [[Dublin]] * 2012: [[Montréal]] * 2013: [[Vienna]] * 2014: [[Antwerp]] * 2015: [[New York City]] * 2016: [[Rome]] * 2017: [[Riga]] * 2018: [[Leipzig]]
===''Répertoire international des sources musicales''=== [[Répertoire International des Sources Musicales|RISM]] was founded in 1953 and deals with the bibliography of sources in music and music literature from [[Music of ancient Greece|Greek antiquity]] up to 1800.
===''Répertoire international de littérature musicale''=== [[Répertoire International de Littérature Musicale|RILM]], founded in 1966, covers music literature through two online databases: RILM Abstracts of Music Literature, which extends from 1967 to the present, and RILM Retrospective Abstracts of Music Literature (RILM Retro), which covers literature from before 1967.
===''Répertoire international d'iconographie musicale''=== RIdIM, founded in 1971, deals with visual materials relating to music.
===''Répertoire international de la presse musicale''=== [[RIPM]], founded in 1980, preserves, reconstructs, and makes available music periodicals originally published from ca. 1760 to 1966. By 2014, RIPM has indexed 215 music periodicals, published 306 printed volumes and a database of more than 726,000 annotated citations. Furthermore, through the RIPM Online Archive and e-Library, RIPM has made available 166 music journals in full-text.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *{{official website|http://www.IAML.info/}} * [https://twitter.com/iaml_aibm IAML-AIBM] on Twitter * [https://www.facebook.com/iamlaibm IAML-AIBM] on Facebook * [http://www.rism.info/ RISM] * [http://rilm.org/ RILM] * [http://www.ripm.org/ RIPM] * [http://www.ridim.org/ RIdIM]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Josh Wolf.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Josh Wolf, March 2009]]
'''Joshua Selassie "Josh" Wolf'''<ref name=sigsn>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3138/is_2_29/ai_n29341439/ |title=Joshua Selassie "Josh" Wolf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808225633/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3138/is_2_29/ai_n29341439/ |archivedate=2013-08-08 |df= }}</ref> (born June 8, 1982) is an [[United States|American]] freelance journalist and internet videoblogger<ref>http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1222780,00.html</ref> who was jailed by a [[United States district court|Federal district court]] on August 1, 2006, for refusing to turn over a collection of [[videotape]]s he recorded during a July 2005 demonstration in [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. Wolf served 226 days in prison at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Dublin]], California, longer than any other journalist in U.S. history has served for protecting source materials.<ref>Burman, Tony, [http://www.cbc.ca/news/about/burman/letters/2007/03/jailed_journalist_a_symbol_of_1.html Jailed Journalist a symbol of Internet Age], "Letters From the Editor in Chief," ''[[CBC News]]'', March 2, 2007</ref> After Wolf released his video outtakes to the public, U.S. District Judge William Alsup ordered his release on April 3, 2007.<ref name=autogenerated1>Egelko, Bob. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/04/03/BAGLRP0PAP4.DTL "Imprisoned freelance journalist to be released"], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', April, 3.</ref> In 2007, Wolf ran for [[mayor of San Francisco]] against incumbent [[Gavin Newsom]] (finishing in 8th place with about 1 percent of the vote).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cbs5.com/localwire/localfsnews/bcn/2007/07/05/n/HeadlineNews/MAYOR-WOLF/resources_bcn_html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930023737/http://cbs5.com/localwire/localfsnews/bcn/2007/07/05/n/HeadlineNews/MAYOR-WOLF/resources_bcn_html |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref> The next year Wolf accepted a position at the ''[[Palo Alto Daily Post]]'' where he reported on the [[San Mateo County]] government and that of several cities within the county.<ref>Berton, Justin, [http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Video-blogger-Wolf-now-a-real-journalist-3198880.php Videoblogger Wolf now a real journalist], "Videoblogger Wolf now a real journalist" "[[San Francisco Chronicle]]", Aug. 20, 2008</ref> In 2011, Wolf graduated from the [[UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism]] and his thesis film ''Police Tape'' received the Reva and David Logan Prize for Excellence in Investigative Reporting.
==Early life== Wolf was born in Santa Rosa, California. His parents, Len Harrison and Liz Wolf, divorced when he was a young child; he grew up in [[Wrightwood, California]] with his mother, an elementary school teacher. Wolf's middle name, Selassie, is in honor of Ethiopian Emperor [[Haile Selassie I]].<ref name=sigsn/> His mother was born into a Jewish family, and converted to Christianity, becoming a Messianic Jew and raising Wolf a Christian.<ref>http://www.cuke.com/Cucumber%20Project/interviews/wolf.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://joshwolf.net/blog/2007/02/06/303/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825081715/http://joshwolf.net/blog/2007/02/06/303/ |archivedate=2011-08-25 |df= }}</ref>
Wolf attended Wrightwood Elementary School in [[Wrightwood, California]] and Pinon Mesa Middle School in [[Phelan, California]]. He graduated from [[Serrano High School]] in Phelan, California in 2000. Wolf received a bachelor's degree from [[San Francisco State University]] in 2006, and finished a master's degree at the [[UC Berkeley|University of California Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism]] in 2011.
==The video== Wolf, a video blogger who reported on numerous protest and progressive events, videotaped an anti-[[G8]] [[anarchist]] protest in [[San Francisco]] on July 8, 2005 in which some of the protesters wore masks and vandalized property. Later that same night, and over the next few days, Wolf edited his footage and posted the video to a local activist news website, Bay Area Indymedia, or [[Indybay]].<ref>Wolf, Josh, [http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2005/07/09/17517591.php "Empires Must Fall"], ''[[Indybay]]'', July 8, 2005.</ref> Wolf also sold the video to the television broadcast station [[KRON]] the day after the protest. In the process of documenting protest actions, Wolf had recorded a tense scene of a protester being choked by a police officer and another officer threatening passersby with stun guns. The only other recording that was broadcast nearly as much was a still photograph of a bloody police officer who was injured during the protest, not taken by Wolf. Other activists who posted video and photographs to the Bay Area Indymedia website were contacted by the [[FBI]] seeking their original source materials, but it is unknown how many, if any, turned over their recordings to Federal authorities. Wolf's videotape is the only known source material from the protest to have been sought by subpoena after refusal to turn it over.<ref>"On the Media" report, February 16, 2007 {{cite web|url=http://www.onthemedia.org/episodes/2007/02/16/segments/73800 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930022250/http://www.onthemedia.org/episodes/2007/02/16/segments/73800 |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref> On April 3, 2007, Wolf posted the unpublished footage on his blog<ref>Insurgent, [http://www.joshwolf.net/blog/?p=324 "Watch the Unedited Video"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406172741/http://www.joshwolf.net/blog/?p=324 |date=2007-04-06 }}, ''The Revolution Will Be Televised'', April, 3.</ref> after being assured that he would not have to testify about the footage.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Subpoena and arrest== The [[US District Court]] empaneled a [[grand jury]] to determine whether [[arson]] charges should be brought against some of the protesters on the suspicion that they may have intended to damage a police car by firing a [[bottle rocket]] under it, even though the only official damage reported was a broken tail light. The premise for Federal intervention in a case involving a city police car was that the car was funded in part by Federal dollars. Josh Wolf did not shoot any footage of the car incident. But because he shot other video footage elsewhere during the protest, and the identities of some of the protesters were allegedly known to him, Wolf was targeted by Federal officials. Wolf was [[subpoena]]ed by the court, requiring him to turn over his footage and submit to testifying before the grand jury. Specifically, the FBI subpoenaed him to provide "all documents, writings and recordings related to protest activities conducted in San Francisco" between 6:30 p.m. and 11:59 p.m. on July 8 as well any cameras, recording devices, and his computer.
Wolf refused to comply with the subpoena. His case was picked up by the [[National Lawyers Guild]] who asked a federal magistrate in San Francisco to block the grand jury subpoena, arguing that taking such action would have a [[Chilling effect (term)|chilling effect]] on other journalists covering future protests. U.S. District Judge [[William Alsup]] rejected this argument and ordered Wolf be jailed on August 1, 2006 for [[contempt of court]] until he complied.
A federal appeals court granted him bail on August 31, 2006 and he was released on September 1, although Wolf again refused to comply with the district court order that he produce the videotape. On September 18, 2006 his bail was revoked and Wolf returned to prison on September 22, 2006. The entire [[en banc]] Court of Appeals refused Wolf's subsequent appeals.
February 7, 2007 marked the 169th day of Wolf's imprisonment, surpassing the time served by Vanessa Leggett, a [[Houston]]-based freelancer who was imprisoned for 168 days in 2001 and 2002 for declining to reveal unpublished material about a murder case. Wolf remained in jail for a total of 226 days, the longest time a U.S. journalist has been held in contempt for refusing to divulge sources or unpublished material.
==Release== On April 3, 2007, according to Wolf's lawyer David Greene, prosecutors dropped their insistence that Wolf testify before a grand jury after he posted the unaired video online. With permission from the prosecution, U.S. District Judge William Alsup signed an order requiring Wolf's release from the Federal Correctional Institution in Dublin, California.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Central legal issues== There were a number of important legal issues at dispute in this case, including: * whether journalists can refuse to comply with [[grand jury]] subpoenas, and under what circumstances * whether Wolf meets the legal definition of a journalist and is entitled to those protections * whether the Federal government has [[standing (law)|standing]] in this case
Wolf argued that [[first amendment]] protections allow journalists to refuse to comply when a grand jury is not conducted in good faith. Specifically, Wolf believes that the government wants his video tapes to help them identify people who were participating in the protests, not for actual footage of a crime that was committed. He has also argued that the federal prosecutor's claim for standing is tenuous (based on the fact that federal funds helped to pay for a police car that was damaged), and that the case was brought before a federal grand jury in order to avoid California's [[shield law]]s.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_id=4085&catid=&volume_id=254&issue_id=306&volume_num=41&issue_num=42 |title=Contemplating Wolf | author=Sarah Phelan | publisher=San Francisco Bay Guardian | date=2007-07-17 | accessdate=2007-07-19}}</ref> There is no Federal Shield Law at this time.
The Federal prosecutor argued that Wolf does not meet the statutory definition of a journalist (under California law) or a common law journalist's privilege based on the [[Federal Rules of Evidence]]. Further, they argued that even if he did, the protections afforded to journalists would not cover his activities in this case because he merely observed the incidents he recorded in a public place. He did not prompt them, nor did he offer anyone anonymity or confidentiality.
District Court Judge Alsup refused to address any of these issues in his written ruling. He simply signed an order written by the Federal prosecutor that ordered Wolf be jailed because it had been established that he was not complying with a grand jury subpoena.<ref>https://ecf.cand.uscourts.gov/doc1/03513249561</ref>
In their written ruling, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] ruled against Wolf on all three issues.
==Responses== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Josh Wolf event poster 9-21-06 ver2.0.jpg|right|thumb|Josh Wolf event poster 9-21-06 ver2.0]] --> Questions of Wolf's legitimacy as a journalist have been answered by support from various journalist groups. For example, on August 23, 2006 (22 days ''after'' Wolf was incarcerated), The [[Society of Professional Journalists]] awarded him their Journalist of the Year "for upholding the principles of a free and independent press."<ref>http://www.spj.org/ldf-a.asp</ref> The SPJ described Wolf as "...a California blogger and freelance journalist..." Josh Wolf was the only journalist jailed for his professional activities in the [[United States]] in 2006, according to [[Committee to Protect Journalists]]<ref>http://www.cpj.org/attacks06/pages06/imprison_06.html#usa</ref> (this organization is a member of [[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]]). Support in the journalistic community is not uniform, however. On February 28, 2007, syndicated columnist [[Debra Saunders]] attacked the credibility of Wolf's arguments, namely the lack of an expectation of privacy of those he was filming.
In a televised interview on February 9, 2007, Wolf and his attorney, [[Martin Garbus]], responded to the question of the legitimacy of federal involvement, by claiming that the legal efforts against Wolf were part of a broader attempt by the government to learn the identity of people within the video who are critical of the Bush administration and to suppress American journalism at large.
Wolf stated during his portion of the interview via phone from prison that he has offered to allow the judge to review "[[in camera]]" the raw footage to determine if there's any applicable evidence within the video and the U.S. Attorney's office refused the offer based on a legal technicality. Wolf also said that the raw video does not offer any more applicable evidence of the arson or assault charges.
The U.S. Attorney's office declined to participate in the interview but a spokesperson sent a statement saying they were obligated to gather evidence and that six separate judges have "... ruled that this office has issued a lawful subpoena for legitimate investigative purposes ...".
The Rise Up Network Legal Fund held a benefit to help free Josh Wolf and the media in general on September 21, 2006. Featured speakers included [[Ross Mirkarimi]], [[Chris Daly]], and [[Judith Miller (journalist)|Judith Miller]].
After Josh Wolf took a job as a general assignment reporter at the Palo Alto Daily Post in 2008, he had some choice words for critics who have questioned his claim of being a journalist.
"If the haters who said I wasn't a real journalist, are still lurking," Wolf wrote on his blog, "I hope you don't have too much indigestion after eating your words.'<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-08-20/news/17124347_1_video-blogger-police-officer-stories | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=Video blogger Wolf now a real journalist | first=Justin | last=Berton | date=August 20, 2008}}</ref>
==Candidacy for mayor== {{See also|San Francisco mayoral election, 2007}}
On July 4, 2007, Wolf announced his candidacy for the office of Mayor of San Francisco, against incumbent [[Gavin Newsom]]. Promising an "open and transparent government", Wolf stated he would wear a video camera everywhere he does his mayoral business.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://cbs5.com/localwire/localfsnews/bcn/2007/07/05/n/HeadlineNews/MAYOR-WOLF/resources_bcn_html | title=SF: FORMERLY JAILED JOURNALIST JOSH WOLF TO RUN FOR MAYOR | publisher=Bay City News Wire | date=2007-07-05 | accessdate=2007-07-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930023737/http://cbs5.com/localwire/localfsnews/bcn/2007/07/05/n/HeadlineNews/MAYOR-WOLF/resources_bcn_html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-30}}</ref> His platform<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joshwolf.net/blog/?p=350 |title=I'm running for mayor |author=Josh Wolf |work=The Revolution Will Be Televised |publisher=joshwolf.net |date=2007-07-04 |accessdate=2007-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824002314/http://joshwolf.net/blog/?p=350 |archivedate=2007-08-24 |df= }}</ref> also discussed homelessness, crime, transportation, public works, gay marriage, medical marijuana and other issues.
Wolf finished in 8th place with 1.24% of votes cast.
== See also ==
* [[Greg Anderson (trainer)]] * [[Judith Miller (journalist)]]

{{Multiple issues| {{overly detailed|date=March 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2012}} }}
{{Infobox person | name =Julien Anfruns | image =Julien Anfruns.jpg | image_size = | caption = | occupation = Senior Civil Servant, Member of the [[Council of State (France)]] | website = [http://www.conseil-etat.fr/en/ French Conseil d’Etat - Official website] }}
'''Julien Anfruns''' is a Member of the [[Council of State (France)]] ('Conseil d'Etat'), Supreme Court Judge.
Between 2008<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lejournaldesarts.fr/site/archives/docs_article/59241/julien-anfruns-a-la-tete-de-l-icom.php |title=Julien Anfruns at the head of ICOM|date=October 2010|publisher=''lejournaldesarts.fr''|language=fr}}</ref> and May 2013, Julien Anfruns was the Director General of the [[International Council of Museums]] (ICOM). On the occasion of the 2010 World Expo (''[[Expo 2010]]'') in [[Shanghai]], [[China]], ICOM held its 22nd General Conference between 7 and 12 November,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.china.org.cn/arts/2009-11/13/content_18881469.htm |title=Shanghai to host world museum convention|year=2009|publisher=''china.org''}}</ref> during which Julien Anfruns welcomed among others, the former President of France, [[Jacques Chirac]], as well as the former President of [[Mali]], [[Alpha Oumar Konaré]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icom.museum/news/news/article/jacques-chirac-and-alpha-oumar-konare-at-the-icom-general-conference.html |title=Jacques Chirac and Alpha Oumar Konaré at the ICOM General Conference|year=2010|publisher=''ICOM''}}</ref>
Julien Anfruns was educated at the National School of Administration ([[École nationale d'administration]], ENA) and [[EDHEC Business School]]. He was the Director of Administration, for Financial and Legal Affairs (C.F.O. and General Counsel) at the Louvre Museum<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000000265070&dateTexte=&categorieLien=id |title=Julien Anfruns, Director of Administration, Financial and Legal Affairs at the Louvre Museum|publisher=''legifrance.gouv.fr''|language=fr}}</ref> ([[Musée du Louvre]]) between 2005-2008, where he was involved in the strategic development of the Louvre both in France and abroad, notably for the project [[Louvre Abu Dhabi]]. He has also previously occupied several diplomatic posts including at the [[United Nations]] in [[New York City|New York]], as well as in [[Finland]] and [[Estonia]].
He is actively involved as a member of several think tank groups, including the Global Agenda Council on the Role of the Arts in Society<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/global-agenda-councils/julien-anfruns|title=Julien Anfruns|publisher=''www.weforum.org''}}</ref> for the [[World Economic Forum]] ([[Davos]]). In April 2013, he was nominated as a member to the French national commission of the European Heritage Label.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.culturecommunication.gouv.fr/En-pratique/Protections-labels-et-appellations/Le-label-du-Patrimoine-europeen |title=Label du Patrimoine européen|publisher=''culturecommunication.gouv.fr''|language=fr}}</ref>
Julien Anfruns also engages in forums bringing together culture and business and participates on panels such as the [[Forum d'Avignon]] and is a member of the Nouveau Club de Paris,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new-club-of-paris.org/|title=New Club of Paris|publisher=''New Club of Paris''}}</ref> which supports Knowledge Economy. He served as a trustee for the [[European Museum Forum]] between January 2010 and February 2013. He is a member of the Advisory Board of [[EDHEC Business School]].
==International Committee of the Blue Shield (ICBS)== Following the second World War ''([[World War II]])'', UNESCO adopted the [[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict|Hague Convention]] (1954) creating rules to protect cultural goods during armed conflicts. This Convention was the first international treaty aimed at protecting [[Cultural heritage]] in the context of war and which highlighted the concept of [[Common heritage]]. The International Committee of the Blue Shield (ICBS) is stated in the protocol of the Hague Convention and was created as the equivalent for Heritage of what the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC) represents for Humanitarian actions. ICBS incorporates museums and archives, audiovisual supports, libraries, and monuments and sites. It brings together the knowledge, experience and international networks of the following non-governmental organisations dealing with cultural heritage: ICA, [[International Council on Archives]], ICOM, International Council of Museums, IFLA, [[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]], ICOMOS, [[International Council on Monuments and Sites]] and CCAAA, Coordinating Council of Audiovisual Archives Associations. Julien Anfruns was President of the International Committee of the Blue Shield (ICBS) between 2009 and 2013.
==Speeches and contributions== Julien Anfruns is invited to participate at many conferences and contributes on numerous to several international projects. His most recent contributions:
* World Economic Forum, Summit on the Global Agenda, [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] (18–20 November 2013)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/events/summit-global-agenda|title=Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates 18-20 November 2013|year=2013|publisher=''www.weforum.org''}}</ref> * Conference on Intangible Heritage and Territories Attraction, French Ministry of Finance, [[Paris]], 17 October 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economie.gouv.fr/files/files/directions_services/apie/page-breves/2013/Programme_conference_17_octobre.pdf|title=Patrimoine immatériel et territoires (pdf)|year=2013|publisher=''www.economie.gouv.fr''|language=fr}}</ref> * World Economic Forum (Davos, Switzerland) from du 23 to 27 January 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/GAC12/IssueBrief/IB_RoleArtsSociety.pdf|title=The Global Agenda Council on the role of the Arts in Society of the World Economic Forum : insights|year=2013|publisher=''weforum.org''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/sessions/summary/new-centres-innovation|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130416041043/http://www.weforum.org/sessions/summary/new-centres-innovation|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-04-16|title=New Centres of Innovation|year=2013|publisher=''weforum.org''}}</ref> * First Congress of the northern committees of the ICOM Latin America and Caribbean Alliance in [[Guatemala]] (10–12 December 2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prensalibre.com/cultura/museos-deben-atractivos_0_827917288.html|title=Article in la Prenda Libre : "Anfruns : los museos deben ser atractivos"|year=2012|publisher=''prensalibre.com''}}</ref> * [[Forum d'Avignon]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/fr/20121117-semaine-eco-2eme-partie-culture-remede-atnti-crise|title=Interview on France 24 during the Forum d’Avignon 2012: "La culture, un remède anti-crise ?"|year=2012|publisher=''france24.com''|language=fr}}</ref> (France) from 15 to 17 November 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forum-avignon.org/fr/anfruns-julien|title=Session du Forum d’Avignon 2012 avec la participation de Julien Anfruns, intitulée "Organiser le temps – Le musée imaginaire"|year=2012|publisher=''forum-avignon.org''}}</ref> * Summit of the World Economic Forum in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] (12–14 November 2012) * Annual Conference of NEMO<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ne-mo.org/index.php?id=337|title=Detailed program of the 2012 Annual Conference of NEMO in Dublin|year=2012|publisher=''ne-mo.org''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010210621/http://www.ne-mo.org/index.php?id=337|archivedate=2012-10-10|df=}}</ref> (Network of European Museum Organisations) in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]] from 2 to 4 November 2012 * Symposium for the French-speaking Sub-Saharian area’s heritage (Paris, 26 October 2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icom.museum/news/news/article/icom-receives-the-cultural-heritage-directors-of-the-french-speaking-sub-saharan-area/L/0/|title=ICOM receives the cultural heritage directors of the French-speaking Sub-Saharan area|year=2012|publisher=''icom.museum''}}</ref> * AVICOM Conference (International Committee for Audiovisual and New Image and Sound Technologies in Museums) in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]] from 9 to 11 October 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://network.icom.museum/avicom/fiamp-festival/program/L/10/|title=Julien Anfruns at the conference AVICOM Montréal 2012|year=2012|publisher=''icom.museum''}}</ref> * The Best in Heritage Conference in [[Dubrovnik]], [[Croatia]], from 27 to 29 September 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XwU_UF2jtSo|title=Julien Anfruns’ keynote speech during The Best in Heritage Conference in 2012: "Ethics for the heritage sector"|year=2012|publisher=''VIDEO Youtube''}}</ref> * ICOMOS and ICAHM Regional Conference in Greece about heritage protection in times of economic crisis<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.star.gr/Pages/Politismos.aspx?art=108595&artTitle=diethnes_synedrio_gia_tin_prostasia_tis_politistikis_mas_klironomias|title=ICOMOS and ICAHM 2012 Regional Conference about heritage protection in times of economic crisis|year=2012|publisher=''star.gr''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801104054/http://www.star.gr/Pages/Politismos.aspx?art=108595&artTitle=diethnes_synedrio_gia_tin_prostasia_tis_politistikis_mas_klironomias|archivedate=2013-08-01|df=}}</ref> (23–25 May 2012) * The IBA Art, Cultural institutions and Heritage Law Committee’s conference about “New Art: New Legal Challenges” at the MAXXI (Roma, 17–18 May 2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fondazionemaxxi.it/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/RomeNewArt2012programmefinal-1.pdf |title=The IBA Art, Cultural institutions and Heritage Law Committee’s conference 2012|year=2012|publisher=''fondazionemaxxi.it''}}</ref> * The 2012 Council of Europe Museum Prize at a Ceremony held in Strasbourg on 25 April 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanmuseumforum.info/emf/news/60-council-of-europe-museum-prize-ceremony.html|title=The 2012 Council of Europe Museum Prize at a Ceremony held in Strasbourg on 25 April 2012|year=2012|publisher=''europeanmuseumforum.info''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722143432/http://www.europeanmuseumforum.info/emf/news/60-council-of-europe-museum-prize-ceremony.html|archivedate=22 July 2012|df=}}</ref> * The International Fair of Agriculture for the conference of museums of agriculture on 2 March 2012 * The Irish Museums Association’s conference on 25 February 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishmuseums.org/assets/12-IMA-AbstractsSat.pdf |title=The Irish Museums Association’s conference on 25 February 2012|year=2012|publisher=''irishmuseums.org''}}</ref> * Jury of the contest entitled Musées (em)portables in Paris in January 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6E3vawAohDg |title=Jury of the contest entitled Musées (em)portables in Paris. French VIDEO|date=January 2012|publisher=''VIDEO Youtube''|language=fr}}</ref> * First International Conference of ICBS in Seoul in December 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d_5vqfWYRCM |title=First International Conference of ICBS in Seoul. VIDEO|date=October 2011|publisher=''VIDEO Youtube''}}</ref> * International Bar Association (IBA) Annual Conference in Dubai in October 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibanet.org/ENews_Archive/IBA_28_Sept_2011_Dubai_speakers.aspx |title=International Bar Association (IBA) Annual Conference in Dubai|date=December 2011|publisher=''ibanet.org''}}</ref> * The Best in Heritage Excellence Club at EXPONATEC COLOGNE in November 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WHS8amEepZw |title=The Best in Heritage Excellence Club at EXPONATEC COLOGNE.|date=November 2011|publisher=''VIDEO Youtube''}}</ref>
==Bibliography== {{Refbegin}} * Art Collecting Legal Handbook, Préface Julien Anfruns, Bruno Boesch et Massimo Sterpi (editors), 2013, {{ISBN|978-0414026933}} * Julien Anfruns: ''The Best in Heritage 2012 Publication'', Julien Anfruns’ keynote speech Ethics for the heritage sector, [http://www.thebestinheritage.com/conference/library/ Web] * André Desvallées, François Mairesse: ''Dictionnaire encyclopédique de muséologie'', Préface Julien Anfruns, Armand Colin, 2011, {{ISBN|978-2200270377}}

page.title: List of FIFA World Cup records
